Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Microbiology of the Built Environment GRC

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Americans spend more than 90% of their time in buildings, where the majority of hazardous and beneficial microbial exposures occur, and better information of how this impacts human health is needed. This proposal requests support to help defray costs of 14 junior scientists and engineers to participate in the inaugural Gordon Research Conference on the Microbiology of the Built Environment at the University of New England in Biddeford, ME. The requested funds will provide a diverse mix of research levels, expertise, and experience to achieve specific objectives to foster and grow the emerging scientific, engineering and medical community that has assembled to study microbes and human health in buildings. This proposal benefits society by facilitating communication of scientific progress towards the protection of human wellbeing.

The field of building microbiology seeks to understand how building design, occupancy, and operation impact human exposure to microbes and ultimately how these microbial exposures impact wellbeing. Environmental engineers, architects, microbial ecologists, immunologists, physicians, and epidemiologists populate this emerging field. A single conference venue is needed to exchange research results, build collaborations from researchers in disparate fields, and to foster this interdisciplinary community of researchers. Towards this, the proposal has the overall objective of bringing together researchers on the frontiers of microbiology, building engineering, and health to extend, foster, and grow the emerging scientific, engineering and medical communities to study microbes and human health in buildings. The major innovation of this conference is the focus on integrating the built environment research with microbial assessment and human health. In recent years, microbial ecology, enabled by high throughput DNA sequencing has dominated much of the field. At least 50% of all invited talks will address some aspect of health in the built environment, with the remainder addressing novel
topics on ecology and building engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first Gordon Research Conference on the Microbiology of the Built Environment; Integrating Human Health with Building Microbiomes included expert speakers, poster sessions, and an interactive agenda - all focused on the ecology, control, and positive and negative health impacts of microbes, viruses, allergens and biotoxins in buildings. The Conference was chaired by Dr. Jordan Peccia, Yale University, and was held at the University of New England on the southern coast of Maine with outstanding outdoor recreation opportunities which allowed for informal interactions during the afternoon free sessions. The intention of the conference was to build a strong conference and tradition in this field.

The contributions raised were used to support travel and registration for every student, post doc, and early career scientist who applied as well as a large group of student and professional scientists from underrepresented groups in engineering, biology, and medicine. The conference program quality was excellent and the feedback from the attendees was very positive feedback and included comments about the high-quality level of science, diverse speakers and perspectives, excellent discussion and poster sessions, and helpful networking and mentoring opportunities. 

The nine sessions included topics on How the Built Environment Microbiome Impacts the Human Microbiome, Building Design and Operation Impact Microbial Diversity and Exposure, Viruses in Buildings, Building Microbes, Allergies and Asthma, Mold in Buildings, Pathogens in Premise Plumbing, Pathogens in Buildings, Control of Pathogen Transmission in Buildings and Control of Pathogen Transmission in Buildings 

The conference held a Power Hour on Monday afternoon organized by Dr. Kerry Kinney from the University of Texas at Austin. The Power Hour was an optional informal gathering open to all meeting participants. It was designed to help address the challenges women face in science and support the professional growth of women in our communities by providing an open forum for discussion and mentoring.
